text: United.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Stand with us in caring for our veterans.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Imagine.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Imagine being denied an apartment because of your religion or your race or because you have children or a disability.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's so wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Yes, but who has the power to stop this?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You do.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Each of us has the power.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The law is on your side.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's illegal for landlords to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, disability, or familial status.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you suspect that you have experienced housing discrimination, file a complaint with HUD immediately so we can investigate it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Fair housing is your right.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Use it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: To learn more, visit HUD.gov slash fairhousing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That's HUD.gov slash fairhousing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A public service message from HUD in partnership with the National Fair Housing Alliance.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Welcome back to the Florida Roundtable.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I'm Bill Mick, along with Florida Secretary of State Cord Byrd.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Mr. Secretary, appreciate you taking the time.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It's good to have you along this weekend.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Great to be back.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Let's talk real quickly about the wrap-up of an election.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: There is testing of the election tabulation equipment, logic and accuracy testing in every county.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And I guess you guys, you maintain those records.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Those come into you after the fact.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Let's talk about your confidence level and how Florida conducts these elections right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Great question.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And Florida has 24, 25 years of working on this and getting it right to where we are the best in the country.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Do not take me back to hanging chads.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So you nailed it.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we've had a lot of time to get this right.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I do have tremendous confidence.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And one of the things that we do in Florida that I wish other states would adopt is.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: is that no voting system, meaning something that accepts a ballot, can be used by a county unless it's first certified by the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we have a team of people that'll break the machines down, try to break them, try to mess with them, try to make them operate improperly.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So before any supervisor can use a system, it's first certified by the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then you mentioned logic and accuracy testing.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: That's a public event where the supervisors
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: take a random sampling of the machines, run sample ballots through them, make sure that the ballots that go through or the ballots that are the results that are tabulated, that's open to the public.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then once again, at the end of the day, we have the paper ballot and our state law says that the paper ballot is the best evidence of the voter's intent.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So if we do have one of those close elections and we need to go to the tape, so to speak, we have those paper ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so that's why I'm confident in the outcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: In Brevard County and other counties around the state, I'm not sure if it's every county, we have this clear audit system that after the ballots are run through the actual tabulation equipment, this is a totally separate, not online system at all, not connected to any of the voting mechanism, but it basically, they run the ballots through that and verify by a separate system that everything was right.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: No, you're absolutely right.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It's a great system.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we have about 30 of the county's
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: that are using that system now.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We're proposing that, hoping that the legislature will fund a grant to allow all 67 counties to be able to utilize this system.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And as you mentioned, it's completely separate.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So it's a check on the tabulators.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we have the logic and accuracy testing.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We go through that with the machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Then we have clear audit, which is a 100 percent audit of the race.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We know after 2020, you know, auditing of the elections was a big issue.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Now we would have with this system.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So for Brevard County, you have a 100 percent audit in place, which once again should give confidence to the voters that the tabulations are correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Most certainly one of the complaints we hear around the country.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I don't know how much Florida is impacted by this, but the threat of, if not actual non-citizen voting, some places around the country allow non-citizens to vote in local elections and the like.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Um, is that becoming an issue?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Is that an issue that you hear about a lot?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I do.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I mean, it, I would say that nationwide, it is the number one election integrity topic.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Um,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: currently out there.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And here's the challenge.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I was back in May, I testified before a congressional committee about non-citizen voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And the real issue we have is with federal law that prevents states from doing certain list maintenance activities and getting the information we need on non-citizens before they're added to the voter roll.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So, for example, the U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Constitution says the federal government has complete authority over who becomes
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: a naturalized citizen.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We had 94,000 Floridians become naturalized or non-citizens become naturalized in Florida just in 2023 alone.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: That's a big number.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so what happens because of federal law, if the person fills out the voter application, voter registration form,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: If they perjure themselves and say they're a U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: citizen and turn it in, we have to do the verification on the back end.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We're doing that work every single day.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We're getting information from a variety of places.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But before we remove someone from the voter rolls, we've got to make sure we have the right John Smith.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we don't what we don't want to do is remove someone who is a US citizen who has become naturalized.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And sometimes that happens.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I'm happy to say that Congress listened to us.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: One of my proposals actually made it into the bill.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It was ended up being amended.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: That would require the federal government to send to the states every month a list of who becomes a naturalized citizen.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then we can take that list and then run that against our voter registration database.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Unfortunately, it's stalled in the in the U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Senate.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And you can imagine the reason why.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But the good news is that Congress is listening.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They know it's a problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we're going to continue doing everything legally that we can do.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: to remove non-citizens from the voter rolls because every non-citizen that votes cancels out the vote of a citizen.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So this is really important, but we need the help of the feds, and I'm happy to say that they are finally paying attention.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I'm glad to hear that they are listening to people like you that are in a position of managing these elections across the state and across the country and actually talk to the people on the ground.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I had a situation a few years ago where our former supervisor of elections was being called to Tallahassee to testify to a Senate or House committee regarding election law, and they take the six-hour drive, and they're told to get one minute to speak.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You're not listening to the people if you don't give them time to tell you what's going on.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I would like to see our legislature give the same reception to supervisors that you got when you went to Washington.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I will say, you know, they they do ask questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You know, I serve with many of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They they contact me all the time asking questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: What can they do to improve?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I mean, they want to get it right there.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They got to get elected.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They're going to be on the ballot again.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They are on the ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They all of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You know, they're all up this this cycle.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So, yeah, I know that sometimes it's frustrating for people when they come to a committee with limited time.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They don't get to get a full hearing.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But I know the supervisors are here during the legislative session.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They're making the rounds, going and talking to legislators.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we work hard to try to be on the same page and get it right to make sure that we have the best election code in the country.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You mentioned that federal cooperation you're looking for.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Another area where I would think would be emphasized is a good system for ensuring the people who snowbird or people who live here part of the year and split residency, whatever it may be, aren't voting in multiple states in a federal election.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: That seems pretty hard to track down right now.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And in some cases I'm aware of, the local prosecutors won't handle that.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: An election fraud case is if it's something serious when you've got someone who's voted in, say, New Mexico and Florida.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Well, that's why the legislature and the governor's leadership a few years ago created the Office of Election Crimes and Security, which is within the Department of State, something that I oversee.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And so we have a dedicated unit that is looking at these double voters in multiple states.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We've had several prosecutions done.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Just a few weeks ago, two Florida appellate courts confirmed that the statewide prosecutor has jurisdiction all over the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So if we have a local prosecutor who's maybe not interested or doesn't care about prosecuting these cases, the statewide prosecutor can.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So we take our election law seriously in Florida.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We have a unit dedicated to enforcing them in partnership with the FDLE.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So once again, those are some of the things that we're doing when it's not quote unquote election season.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: that we're still constantly talking to other states, looking at the voter rolls, comparing and seeing when someone moves out of the state of Florida and we know we get information that they're a registered voter and in the other state we're contacting that state saying, hey, did you know that person has moved to your state or vice versa?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Somebody moves into the state and they say, hey, I came from
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: New York, and we're contacting them saying, you know, hey, this person is now here.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They've registered to vote.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You can remove them off of your role.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So those are some of the things that we do in the off season.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And even during the season of elections is getting that, doing that voter list maintenance activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Forgive me for a political question during an elections administration session here, but would a national voter registration make sense in that regard?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You know, the question then becomes who houses the information?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I would not be confident in the federal government housing that database.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I can understand that, sure.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So why it seems your logic is not incorrect, I would be very hesitant to put all of that database of all 50 states with all of the registered voters in the hands of D.C.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: For all of our
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The warps that our system has in 50 different jurisdictions with different philosophies on elections and why that can cause frustrations, I think that the potential evil that could come from having it all in one place is outweighed by
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: you know, sometimes when we see it happen in other states.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Sure.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: How difficult is it to run down that person who's double voted in a couple of states?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I know the ERIC system is no longer in play for the state of Florida that lets you validate with some states instantly.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So that sounds like investigation time there.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It does.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And we're entering into memorandum of understanding with other states to help us do that.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I mean, let's, you know,
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: To be fair, you know, Eric, all 50 states weren't in Eric.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So you still only had a certain segment of the country that was in it.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: California and New York, two of the four largest states, were not in Eric.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So it was an imperfect system.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But we have the states that are cooperative with us.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And most of the people that are going between states tend to be your neighboring states.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So...
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I've got to end it there for the moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: We'll be back with Secretary of State Cord Byrd on the Florida Roundtable.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Welcome back to the Florida Roundtable.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Bill Mick with Secretary of State Cord Byrd.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And Mr. Secretary, let's talk about the tight races that we've... The governor had one with his first election.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: There are automatic triggers for recounts.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Let's talk about those for a minute.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Should we have a tight race in any of these jurisdictions in Florida?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So my first suggestion is that everybody win big.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: That's what I tell all candidates.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And if you can win big, but sometimes that doesn't happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You know, I was part of the I was one of the lawyers during the recount in 2018 in Duval County.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But under state law, if you are within one half of one percent, it automatically triggers a machine recount.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So they they recount the same ballots and see if we get the same number.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: If then, after that machine recount, it's within a quarter percent, then there is a hand recount of over and under votes.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So does that make sense?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So if the machines, if somebody, they then look at over and under, the canvassing board looks at those, and then there's a hand recount of those votes.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: To see if there's any further discrepancy.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So overvotes being too many names marked on that particular race in a ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Undervotes meaning none were marked in that race.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And you'd be amazed at the different ways in which voters mark ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Another one of my favorites.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You know, admonitions is please fill in the ovals correctly.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: No stray marks.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Don't circle parties.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Because that leads to potentially recounts where then you have a canvassing board trying to divine the voter.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: um you know the voter intent while we're there i'm sorry while we're there let's talk about voters in the polling place either early voting or on election day they make a mistake marking their ballot there are ways to correct it on that ballot but they can also turn that ballot in and get a second one once that first one's destroyed right you get you get two mulligans so you get your first ballot and you get up to two more ballots if you make a mistake after that then you're out of luck so
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And those and those ballots are destroyed.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: If you make a mistake, you take that up to the clerk.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The clerk will spoil what we call spoil the ballot, meaning destroy it.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We have we have procedures in place for every polling place.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So that's done consistently throughout the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It's done in front of the voter.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So the mistaken or spoiled ballot is destroyed.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then are you made where it can't be counted?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then they're given an alternate replacement ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Outstanding.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Now, what if a candidate, for some reason, has a challenge in an election?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Do they have the ability to request or demand, in any case, a recount?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Only if it falls within those mandatory recount numbers.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: I mean, a candidate does not have...
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: They don't have the right to demand a recount.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Okay, so if they allege some nefarious behavior by an opponent or maybe a mistake by a supervisor of elections office somewhere, that's lawsuit territory at that point?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Their recourse would then be to the courts.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You've been in some of those battles, at least back in, what, 2000, as I recall?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Yeah, yeah, yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So I was a young lawyer back in 2000 in Palm Beach County.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So, yeah, tangentially involved in that and drafting motions and all that good stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: You've got two advocating sides at that point, both of them trying to present their best argument.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: How much of those end up being focused in actual law or opinion as to why my guy should win?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Yeah, I mean, that's certainly a lot of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And when I give talks around the state, you know, if you're trying to litigate your way to victory, that's usually a losing proposition.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: The courts are very reluctant to change the outcome or the results of an election.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I think rightfully so.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: We don't want, you know, I mean, for the, you know, take the U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Supreme Court, for example, you don't want non-elected or, you know, unelected lawyers in robes, you know, deciding who our president's going to be typically.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: It's not a good thing for
speaker: SPEAKER_03
